projectPurpose: To enable users with standalone VR headsets to wirelessly play PC-based VR games and experiences that require a powerful computer, by acting as a bridge between the PC running SteamVR and the standalone headset over a Wi-Fi network.
mainFeatures: Wireless VR streaming from PC via Wi-Fi
Supports multiple standalone VR headsets (Quest, Pico, Vive Focus, etc.)
Requires SteamVR on the PC
Utilizes hardware video encoding (NVENC, AMF)
Supports Linux and Windows on PC

alternatives.name: Oculus Air Link
mainFeatures: Wireless PC VR streaming for Meta Quest headsets
Integrated into official Meta Quest software
Requires compatible Windows PC and 5GHz Wi-Fi
Low latency streaming

alternatives.name: Steam Link
mainFeatures: Stream SteamVR games to Meta Quest headsets wirelessly
High-fidelity wireless streaming
Requires PC running Steam and SteamVR, and 5GHz Wi-Fi
Supports hand and eye tracking passthrough

alternatives.name: Virtual Desktop
mainFeatures: Stream PC VR games wirelessly to standalone headsets
View computer desktop in VR
Supports multiple monitors
Includes video streaming

alternatives.name: Immerse
mainFeatures: Centralized platform for VR/AR/MR content management
Enterprise VR training and simulation focus
Integrates with LMS and MDM
Data analytics and reporting

marketPositioning: ALVR is positioned as a free and open-source alternative for wireless PC VR streaming. Its key differentiators include support for a wider range of standalone VR headsets beyond just Meta Quest and compatibility with Linux on the PC side. While proprietary solutions like Virtual Desktop and platform-specific options like Oculus Air Link and Steam Link dominate the consumer market, ALVR serves users seeking flexibility, open development, and support for non-mainstream hardware or operating systems. It competes directly on the core functionality of wireless PC VR streaming while offering a community-driven, customizable experience.
